alert.note: Alert for Washington (Vermont) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Burlington (Northern Vermont and New York)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued July 10 at 7:18PM EDT until July 11 at 12:29PM EDT by NWS Burlington
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Vermont... Winooski River At Montpelier affecting Washington County. For the Winooski River...including Montpelier...Major flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL EARLY TOMORROW AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Major flooding is occurring and major flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Winooski River at Montpelier. * WHEN...Until early tomorrow afternoon. * IMPACTS...At 17.5 feet, Water covers the streets in downtown Montpelier. Local roads along the Winooski from Montpelier to Waterbury will be covered in water, and there will be widespread field flooding. At 22.0 feet, Downtown Montpelier will be inundated, and local roads will be covered by water. Route 2 and railroad tracks along the river will be covered with water. There will be widespread field flooding throughout the Winooski River valley. This stage is equivalent to the FEMA 1 Percent Annual Chance Flood. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 6:45 PM EDT Monday the stage was 18.9 feet. - Bankfull stage is 15.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 6:45 PM EDT Monday was 18.9 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 22.7 feet just after midnight tonight. It will then fall below flood stage tomorrow morning. This is a serious situation! Sections of the City of Montpelier are expected to be inundated by high water this evening into tonight. - Flood stage is 15.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued late tonight at 430 AM EDT.
